msContents.summary: The Pañcarakṣā corpus ("Five Protections") consists of the Mahāpratisarā, Mahāmāyūrī, Mahāsāhasrapramardanī, Mahāmantrānusāriṇī, and Mahāśītavatī. The earliest evidence for texts grouped together as the "Five Great Dhāraṇīs" comes from Tibetan catalogues around 800 CE, but this compendium is somewhat different from the surviving Sanskrit collection, which is preserved in manuscripts dating back to the eleventh century. These scriptures include spells, enumerations of benefits and ritual instructions for use. With the course of time all of them became deified and five related goddesses emerged. It is, however, important to note that the texts themselves do not have any references to these goddesses. The kernel of this composite manuscript probably dates back to the 12th century. The many replament folios are from a much more recent date.

msItem.title: Pañcarakṣā
msItem.incipit: [1v1] evaṃ mayā śrutam ekasmin samaye bhagavān rāja:%gṛhe viharati sma || gṛdhrakūṭe parvate dakṣiṇe pārśve buddhagocare ratnavṛkṣe prabhāse va:% -25-
msItem.explicit: [75v5] || oṃ varade hūṃ hariṇi sphuṭāriṇi: (Near the very end of the Mahāmāyūrī)
msItem.finalRubric: [109r2] ||| ^^^ || āryamahāpratisarā mahāvidyārajñī rakṣāvidhānakalpo % vidyādharasyāyaṃ sa-1-māptaḥ || ^^^ || samāptā ceyaṃ mahāvidyārājñī [109r3] mahāpratisareti || ^^^ ||
msItem.explicit: [112v4] buddho lokānukampaka ājñāpayati ||: % muñcata muñcata muñcata muñcata || ṅke || mā tiṣṭhata | vidyā tiṣṭhantu | iti vyupa%sāmyantu | nirgacchata nirgacchata nirgacchata nirgacchata || ṅke || bu:

physDesc.p: Composite manuscript consisting of two codicological units (The kernel is a probably 12th-century palm-leaf manuscript; its extant folios are 1, 13, 15, 18-32, 34, 36-40, 42-44, 46-48, 51, 53-54, 57, 59, 61, 63, 77, 79-85, 88, 90-91, 94, 100-105, 107-112. The second codicological unit consists of 28 replacement folios, probably to be dated from the 14th to the 16th century and numbered as 2, 4-12, 14, 16-17, 19, 64-66, 68, 70, 75, 86-87, 92, 95-99.).

supportDesc.extent: 88 ff. (folios 3, 33, 35, 41, 45, 49-50, 52, 55-56, 58, 60, 62, 67, 69, 71-74, 76, 78, 89, 93, 106 and a couple of folios at the very end are missing).
supportDesc.condition: Incomplete, in generally passable condition. All margins are frayed, sometimes with loss of the text (especially the first folio).

bindingDesc.stringHole: Two string holes (one of the string holes in the back cover is bolted).

decoNote.desc: Both the front cover and the back cover are finely carved with a floral pattern.

history.provenance:
Bought in Nepāl by Prof. C. Bendall Bendall, Cecil
in 1884-5.

layout.p: 4 lines per page, approximately 74 akṣaras per line.
layout.stringHole: Two string holes. The string holes are approximately in the middle of 2 cm-wide blank spaces, framed by double parallel lines in black ink. These are identical to those found on the outer margins of the written area, which is therefore divided into three sections.
layout.p: In the Mantrānusāriṇī, two symbols approximately resembling the characters 'ja' and 'ṅke' are sometimes employed to divide the various mantras.

handNote.desc: First hand: Kuṭila script in black ink (Main text).
Second hand: Nepālākṣarā script in black ink (Marginal corrections, and possibly annotations).

item.marginalia: Some marginal corrections (and possibly annotations) throughout the manuscript.

layout.p: 4-5 lines per page, approximately 105 akṣaras per line.
layout.stringHole: Two string holes. The string holes are approximately in the middle either of 2 cm-wide blank spaces or of a 2 to 2 cm square blank space, surrounded by writing. Thus the written area is sometimes divided into three sections, sometimes just a single block.
